Study of the catalytic reactions of ethylene oligomerization in subcritical and supercritical media over a NiBEA catalyst Gabriel V.S. Seufitelli Fernando L.P. Resende ⁎ University of Washington, School of Environmental and Forest Sciences, Seattle, WA 98195, United States University of Washington, School of Environmental and Forest Sciences Seattle WA 98195 United States ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract We report a study of the catalytic reactions of ethylene oligomerization over nickel impregnated in aluminum silicate using subcritical and supercritical media. We found the BET surface area decreases with increasing nickel loading, indicating the deposition of NiO particles on the catalyst surface, which we confirmed via XRD. We compared the performance of the NiBEA catalyst with the protonated form (HBEA) of the commercial support and obtained strong evidence that the protonated form promotes chain growth reactions. In addition, the introduction of nickel in the catalyst facilitates the desorption of the oligomers compared to the HBEA catalyst. Additionally, we used FTIR and GC–MS/FID to characterize the adsorbed and desorbed oligomers and developed reaction pathways for the ethylene oligomerization over the NiBEA catalyst. We found that both adsorbed and desorbed oligomers are aliphatic, and the non-desorbed products constitute the coke. Additionally, we found that pressure and temperature both increase the chain growth and desorption rates of adsorbed oligomers. Under supercritical conditions, the amount of coke formed on the catalyst and the desorbed products molecular weight both increase relative to subcritical conditions. However, the supercritical conditions promote the dissolution of the coke from both NiBEA and HBEA catalysts, which shows the standalone effect of the supercritical ethylene toward the dissolution of coke from the catalyst surface. We provided visual evidence of (1) the formation of coke on the catalyst surface, and (2) the coke dissolution phenomena under supercritical conditions. Finally, we characterized the coke molecules at supercritical conditions as macromolecules connected via C-C (sp3) bonds with the occurrence of cyclic species. Keywords Ethylene Oligomerization Supercritical Heterogeneous catalysis Coke In situ FTIR 1 Introduction Ethylene (C2H4) is the simplest alkene and one of the most important chemicals from an industrial point of view. Currently, most of the ethylene is produced from the cracking of naphtha, and the production exceeds 140 million tons per year with a 3.5% increase forecast for the next 5 years [1,2]. Most of the ethylene produced today is used as a feedstock in polymerization reactions; however, it can also be used in oxidation, halogenation, alkylation, hydration, and oligomerization, for the production of a vast range of chemicals [3–5]. Ethylene oligomerization has an important role in the production of linear alpha-olefins, which are feedstocks in the production of fuels, lubricants, and surfactants. Additionally, higher alpha-olefins can also undergo oligomerization. The oligomerization of alpha-olefins is a catalytic process which can be performed in homogenous or heterogeneous media [3–5]. However, the difficulty in recycling the catalyst, pricey equipment required to perform the separation of the catalyst from the effluent, and the disposal of non-environmentally friendly chemicals [3–6] led to the development of heterogeneous catalysts for the oligomerization of alpha-olefins [7–9]. The use of heterogeneous catalysts provides a way to overcome some of the problems involved in homogeneous catalysis. Examples of heterogeneous catalysts used in oligomerization reactions are acidic catalysts and nickel supported in inorganic structures. The introduction of nickel in inorganic structures can be achieved using techniques such as ion-exchange, impregnation, and coprecipitation [5]. There is a major interest in the development of nickel exchanged in inorganic structures as heterogeneous catalysts since it is believed that ethylene only undergoes oligomerization over acidic catalysts at very high temperatures, leading to the formation of strongly adsorbed species on the catalyst. Many studies focused on the development of nickel supported in inorganic structures for the ethylene oligomerization [7–9]. These studies tested different nickel exchanged in inorganic supports such as AlMCM-41, amorphous silica-aluminum, and Y zeolite. They studied the effects of temperature, pressure, and weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) on the heterogeneous ethylene oligomerization under subcritical conditions. Ng et al. [9] proposed a reaction mechanism based on the role of the nickel and acid sites on the dimerization of ethylene over nickel exchanged Y zeolite. Hulea et al. [7] proposed a reaction pathway for the oligomerization of ethylene over a Ni-MSA catalyst, accounting for desorbed oligomers formed via oligomerization and isomerization reactions. Furthermore, other studies used FTIR [10–12] to postulate reaction mechanisms to describe the heterogeneous oligomerization reactions over acidic catalysts at very low temperatures; however, they only accounted for adsorbed species, and no information about the desorbed products was reported. Therefore, in this work, we propose to characterize the species formed on the catalyst surface and the liquid product during the heterogeneous ethylene oligomerization over a NiBEA catalyst. We used FTIR to measure the coke formed on the catalyst and collected the liquid products of the reaction. We proposed reaction pathways based on adsorbed and desorbed oligomers involved in oligomerization, isomerization, and cracking reactions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to develop reaction pathways for the ethylene oligomerization over a nickel exchanged catalyst with a BEA (Beta) topology. In addition to the characterization of adsorbed and desorbed products and the development of the reaction pathways, we carried out a comparison of the process at subcritical and supercritical conditions. For nickel supported in microporous inorganic structures, coke formation, and therefore loss of activity, is an issue [7]. Reactions in supercritical media were postulated as a possibility to overcome this problem by promoting dissolution of the coke from the catalyst surface; therefore, prolonging the catalysts lifetime [13–15]. Usually, coke is characterized as polycyclic aromatic molecules [16]. Such molecules, in turn, are more soluble in supercritical fluids than in subcritical fluids, as it has been reported for naphthalene dissolved in ethylene [14]. However, for reactions carried out at temperatures below 200 °C, coke is formed primarily from condensation and rearrangement steps, leading to non-aromatic coke molecules [16]. Nevertheless, it is still believed that supercritical fluids can dissolve this form of coke. Supercritical media has already been used to study the oligomerization of ethylene over HZSM-5 in supercritical n-pentane, and it was reported that the catalyst lifetime was improved by the removal of heavier compounds from the catalyst surface [15]. However, the present paper differs from the work already reported in the literature since (1) the catalyst used is exchanged with nickel and have a BEA topology, which is different than the HZSM-5, and (2) the reactions reported in the present paper are performed in supercritical ethylene, without the presence of another solvent. Additionally, Li et al. [15] suggested the solvent effect of the supercritical ethylene based on the increase of aromatic compounds in the product stream. In the present paper, we show visual evidence of the coke formation on the catalyst surface, and coke dissolution, under supercritical conditions. In summary, we propose a catalytic study of the ethylene oligomerization over a NiBEA catalyst under subcritical and supercritical ethylene conditions by combining the information of adsorbed and desorbed oligomers. Furthermore, we proposed reaction pathways based on the data obtained for adsorbed and desorbed products under the conditions studied. Finally, we compared the effects of the supercritical ethylene conditions on the ethylene oligomerization relative to subcritical conditions, including visual evidence of the coke dissolution phenomena under supercritical conditions. 2 Experimental method 2.1 Material We purchased ammonium exchanged zeolite with a BEA structure, abbreviated as NH4BEA, with a SiO2/Al3O2 = 25 from Zeolyst International. We obtained the protonated form, abbreviated as HBEA, after calcination of the NH4BEA form at 550 °C for 5 hours in the presence of air. We produced the nickel exchanged zeolite, abbreviated as NiBEA, by ion exchange of the NH4BEA form with a 0.51 M solution of Ni(NO3)2 purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. We added the Ni(NO3)2 solution dropwise for 1 h to the NH4BEA powder, producing a slurry which was stirred for 5 h using a Teflon stir bar. Then, we filtered the slurry under vacuum, following with washing in deionized water. After the filtration, we dried the solid at 100 °C overnight. After drying, a material similar to a clay was obtained, which was ground. Finally, we calcined the powder at 550 °C for 5 h to remove the remaining ammonium species and activate the catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization ICP-AES (inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy) analysis was performed using EPA protocol 200.7, in which the catalyst samples were digested with nitric acid and hydrochloric acid, to calculate the wt% of nickel in the catalyst. We collected IR spectra in an FT-IR Prestige-21 spectrometer (Shimadzu) with a DLATGS detector attached to a DRIFT cell (Harrick Sci.) and an HVC chamber (Harrick Sci.) mounted with a ZnSe window. The use of an environmental chamber allowed in situ analysis of the HBEA and NiBEA catalysts. For the catalyst characterization, we collected spectra using a resolution of 16 cm−1, however, in situations for which identification of peaks was compromised, a 4 cm−1 resolution was used. We used an average of 100 spectra to obtain the final spectrum. Before each characterization experiment, we mixed the catalysts with KBr (>99% FT-IR grade Sigma-Aldrich) with a 5% dilution. Therefore, for each experiment, we diluted 5 mg of catalyst with 95 mg of KBr. We used a nitrogen (>99% Praxair) line attached to the HVC chamber to pre-treat the catalysts before the measurement of the spectrum. The pre-treatment consisted in heating up the catalyst at a heating rate of 200 °C/h up to 500 °C, then maintaining the temperature for 1 hour. The goal of this treatment was to remove adsorbed water and impurities from the surface of the catalyst. After the in situ pre-treatment, we reduced the temperature to 30 °C and collected the spectrum of the activated catalyst. We normalized the spectra of the activated catalyst according to the procedure described elsewhere [17]. However, in this work, we used the framework vibrational mode in the range of 2400–2000 cm−1 to normalize the spectra (as opposed to 1800–1200 cm−1 used in [17]). Therefore, the absorbance in that region was the same for all samples. Finally, N2 adsorption was performed using a Micromeritics TriStar II. Prior to each experiment, we dried the samples overnight (for spent catalysts), then we degassed the samples for 24 hours at 150 °C. 2.3 Reaction system set-up We carried out the oligomerization of ethylene using the HVC chamber (Harrick Sci.) mounted in a Praying Mantis DRIFT (Harrick Sci.). We used a manifold to feed N2 (>99% Praxair) into the reactor during the pre-treatment and C2H4 (99.5% Praxair) during the oligomerization. We collected the liquid products of the reaction using an impinger, which was placed in a dry ice bath at −20 °C, and was attached to the outlet stream of the HVC chamber. We used a heating tape, which we kept at a temperature higher than 160 °C, to avoid condensation of the products inside of the line connecting the HVC chamber and the impinger. We filled the impinger with 10 ml of dichloromethane (DCM), which was used as the solvent, since it is a standard for MS analysis. We analyzed the liquid collected after the reaction using a GC (QP-2010 Ultra Shimadzu) equipped with a capillary column (SH-Rxi-5ms – Shimadzu) with a length of 15 m and an inner diameter of 0.25 mm, and MS and FID detectors, which were used for identification and quantification of the liquid products, respectively. We used the results from the MS to compare the differences in composition between the products which remained adsorbed in the catalyst and the products which were desorbed after the reaction. We used the FID data to calculate the oligomers selectivity for the conditions studied in the current paper, according to Eq. (1): (1) S ( % ) = 100 × m i ∑ j n m j where S (%) is the product selectivity in percentage, m i is the mass of the oligomers, n is the total number of products, and j is the index relative to each one of the products. Since a complex mixture of oligomers was produced, with multiple isomers containing the same number of carbons, the isomers were grouped together. Therefore, we calculated the selectivity in terms of products with number of carbons ranging from C3 to C10+, in which C10+ consists in the oligomers with more than 10 carbons. For some experiments, the C10+ products included compounds with up to 20 carbons. Furthermore, we performed additional experiments using a packed bed reactor (PBR) connected to an online GC-FID (Shimadzu 2014). We used Eq. (2) to calculated the ethylene conversion, in which C (%) is the ethylene conversion, m products is the total mass of products collected, and mass in,ethylene is the total mass of ethylene fed into the system. (2) C ( % ) = 100 × m p r o d u c t s m a s s i n , e t h y l e n e We divided the experimental work into two components. The first component consists in the investigation of the catalytic reactions of ethylene oligomerization (under subcritical and supercritical conditions), referred as effects of reaction conditions and parameters. The second part consisted in the study of the effects of supercritical conditions on the ethylene oligomerization, referred as analysis of the effects of supercritical fluid conditions. The results for each individual component are presented separately. 2.3.1 Effects of reaction conditions and parameters First, we performed a temperature screening (1) to determine at which temperature the formation of coke starts, and (2) to determine the effect of the nickel exchange in the designed catalyst. For all the experiments presented in this section, we diluted the catalyst with KBr using a 5% dilution (5 mg of catalyst with 95 mg of KBr). The possibility of potassium exchanging the NiBEA or HBEA catalysts was evaluated by comparing the product selectivity and ethylene conversion for the ethylene oligomerization over the pure catalyst and a mixture of catalyst and KBr, under the same conditions. These results are shown in Table S1 (Supplementary Information). Mixing the catalyst with KBr had no significant effect on the parameters evaluated in this work. Prior to each experiment, we pre-treated the fresh catalyst by increasing the temperature from 30 to 300 °C with a heating rate of 4 °C/min, under 100 ml/min of nitrogen. We maintained the temperature at 300 °C for 1 h, then we reduced it to 30 °C. We performed the reactions by ramping the temperature from 30 to 300 °C, at ambient pressure 0 bar (gauge), with a heating rate of 4 °C/min, using an ethylene flow rate of 15 ml/min (STD), yielding a WHSV of 226.8 h−1. We collected spectra with resolution of 4 cm−1 over the experiment. We observed that the ethylene peaks originated from the gas phase overlapped with the peaks of the oligomers formed on the catalyst. We prevented this problem by subtracting the ethylene spectra from the final spectra. Therefore, an additional experiment was conducted with pure KBr to collect the spectra of the ethylene in the gas phase using the same conditions as the original experiment. The background subtraction resolved the peaks assigned to the oligomers produced during the process. Moreover, we conducted studies to compare the effects of temperature and pressure on the ethylene oligomerization over the NiBEA catalyst. We used three temperatures (30 °C, 100 °C, 200 °C) and pressures (6.9 bar, 34.5 bar, and 62 bar), based on previous studies performed by our research group using a packed-bed reactor [18–20]. We pressurized the system using an ethylene flow rate of 300 ml/min to minimize chemical reactions during the pressurization process. Once the system was at the reaction pressure, we increased the temperature to the setpoint using a heating rate of 20 °C/min. Finally, after the system was under the desired conditions, we initiated the flow of ethylene into the reactor at 15 ml/min for 100 min (TOS = 100 min). We calculated the WHSV for these experiments to be 226.8 h−1. The spectra of the ethylene gas phase at higher pressures increased significantly, and for this reason, we were not able to perform the subtraction of the ethylene gas phase spectra, which was overlapping with the oligomers spectra. Therefore, for this set of experiments, the spectra of the reacted catalyst were collected only after the reaction, with the objective to identify the nature of the oligomers formed for each condition studied. 2.3.2 Analysis of the effects of supercritical fluid conditions (SCFC) We used supercritical ethylene to study the effects of the SCFC in the solubilization of the coke species adsorbed on the catalyst. To observe and characterize the coke formation phenomena, we used pure catalyst (without KBr) in the HVC chamber. Therefore, we increased the catalyst loading from 5 mg to 55 mg. We used the same pressurization and heating procedures described in Section 2.3.1. However, we increased the ethylene flow rate to 600 ml/min during the pressurization process to avoid reactions over the larger mass of catalyst. For the oligomerization reaction, we set the ethylene flow rate to 165 ml/min. The other variables were the same as in the experiment described in Section 2.3.1. The calculated WHSV for this set of experiments was 226.8 h−1. The experiments at SCFC were divided into two sections. The first section consisted in the study of the conditions listed in Table 1 . Since the ethylene critical temperature and pressure are 9.4 °C and 51.2 bar, respectively, the experiments were designed to compare the effects of the subcritical, supercritical, and dense supercritical media on the ethylene oligomerization over the NiBEA catalyst. We collected pictures of the catalyst surface every 20 min during the dense supercritical experiment to show the coke formation and dissolution phenomena. In the second section, we performed the dense supercritical experiment using a TOS = 50 min, to collect the material formed at the surface of the catalyst. 2.4 Statistical analysis We performed a triplicate of the experiment conducted at 30 °C and 34.5 bar for the set of experiments described at Section 2.3.1. We used this triplicate to calculate the standard deviation of the CH2/CH3 ratio of the oligomers remaining on the catalyst surface after the reaction. Also, we performed a duplicate of the dense supercritical condition presented in Section 2.3.2 to calculate the standard deviation of the product selectivity for the oligomers collected in the impinger. We used this standard deviation for the experiments described in Section 2.3.1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The ICP analysis of the NiBEA catalysts shows nickel loadings of 1.0, 1.5, 2.5, 4.1, and 6.0 wt.%. We used the catalyst with a nickel loading of 4.1 wt.% to perform the reaction experiments based on previous studies from our research group, which showed that the NiBEA catalyst with similar nickel loading is highly active for the production of liquid products and minimizes the formation of coke, under the same temperature and pressure conditions used in the present paper [18–20]. As shown in Fig. 1 A, after the impregnation of the NH4BEA with the Ni(NO3)2 solution, the nickel loading increased with the concentration of the solution, indicating the deposition of nickel particles on the catalyst, however, the relationship is not linear. Also, the BET analysis of the catalysts shows a type IV isotherm (Fig. S1 – Supplementary Information) characteristic of materials containing both microporous and mesoporous structures. The pore distribution plots (Fig. S2 – Supplementary Information) supports the existence of mesoporous structures, however, the textural properties of the catalysts (Table S2 – Supplementary Information) indicate a higher degree of microporous structures (approximately 68%) as compared with mesoporous structures. Additionally, the surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption experiments decreased with increasing Ni(NO3)2 concentration. It is known that the introduction of nickel in the zeolite framework is dictated by ion exchange of Brønsted acid sites for nickel loading below 2.0 wt.%. On the other hand, for nickel loading greater than 2.0 wt.%, wet impregnation takes place, therefore, leading to the formation of NiO clusters on the catalyst surface, which blocks the catalyst pore structure and theoretically can cause a reduction in surface area as presented in Fig. 1A [3]. Furthermore, analysis of the pore volume for the NiBEA catalysts (Supplementary Information – Fig. S2 and Table S2) shows a decrease in the microporous and mesoporous volume with increasing nickel loading beyond 1.5 wt.% nickel. The nickel loading affects the mesoporous structures more strongly than it affects microporous structures at nickel loadings greater than 1.5 wt.%, indicating the formation of large NiO particles on the catalyst with increasing nickel loading. Therefore, the effect of NiO particles on both surface area and pore volume suggests that NiO clusters might block the pore structure of the NiBEA at higher nickel loadings. To validate this hypothesis we performed XRD measurements of the NiBEA catalysts with 1.0, 4.1, and 6.0 wt.% nickel loadings, which patterns are presented in Fig. 2 . It is possible to observe reflections at 37.2, 43.4, and 62.9 (marked with *) for NiBEA catalysts with 4.1 and 6.0 wt.% nickel loadings. According to Martinez et al., these reflections are assigned to (111), (200), and (220) planes of fcc-NiO phase [6]. Additionally, the NiBEA catalyst with 6.0 wt.% nickel loading shows increased intensity for NiO species as compared with the NiBEA catalysts containing 1.0 and 4.1 wt.% nickel. It is important to highlight that the absence of reflections for NiO species on the NiBEA catalyst with a nickel loading of 1.0 wt.% does not guarantee the absence of NiO species, because small NiO clusters might still be presented on the catalyst structure. However, these NiO clusters are smaller for the NiBEA catalyst with a nickel loading of 1.0 wt.% compared with the NiBEA catalysts containing 4.1 and 6.0 wt.% nickel. Therefore, (1) the increase in the intensity of the peaks assigned to NiO with increasing nickel loading and consequently (2) reduction of the catalyst surface area measured by N2 adsorption experiments supports the hypothesis that large NiO clusters are formed on the NiBEA catalysts with increasing nickel loading and they block the pores of the catalyst, causing a reduction in surface area. A similar result was obtained by Martinez et al. using the same catalyst [6]. The ICP analysis of the NiBEA catalysts shows nickel loadings of 1.0, 1.5, 2.5, 4.1, and 6.0 wt.%. Additionally, the surface area calculated from the N2 adsorption experiments decreased with increasing Ni(NO3)2 concentration. It is known that the introduction of nickel in the zeolite framework is dictated by ion exchange of Brønsted acid sites for nickel loading below 2.0 wt.%. On the other hand, for nickel loading greater than 2.0 wt.%, wet impregnation takes place, therefore, leading to the formation of NiO clusters on the catalyst surface, which blocks the catalyst pore structure and theoretically can cause a reduction in surface area as presented in Fig. 1A [3]. Furthermore, analysis of the pore volume for the NiBEA catalysts (Supplementary Information – Fig. S2 and Table S2) shows a decrease in the microporous and mesoporous volume with increasing nickel loading beyond 1.5 wt.% nickel. The nickel loading affects the mesoporous structures more strongly than it affects microporous structures at nickel loadings greater than 1.5 wt.%, indicating the formation of large NiO particles on the catalyst with increasing nickel loading. Therefore, the effect of NiO particles on both surface area and pore volume suggests that NiO clusters might block the pore structure of the NiBEA at higher nickel loadings. To validate this hypothesis we performed XRD measurements of the NiBEA catalysts with 1.0, 4.1, and 6.0 wt.% nickel loadings, which patterns are presented in Fig. 2 . It is possible to observe reflections at 37.2, 43.4, and 62.9 (marked with *) for NiBEA catalysts with 4.1 and 6.0 wt.% nickel loadings. According to Martinez et al., these reflections are assigned to (111), (200), and (220) planes of fcc-NiO phase [6]. Additionally, the NiBEA catalyst with 6.0 wt.% nickel loading shows increased intensity for NiO species as compared with the NiBEA catalysts containing 1.0 and 4.1 wt.% nickel. It is important to highlight that the absence of reflections for NiO species on the NiBEA catalyst with a nickel loading of 1.0 wt.% does not guarantee the absence of NiO species, because small NiO clusters might still be presented on the catalyst structure. However, these NiO clusters are smaller for the NiBEA catalyst with a nickel loading of 1.0 wt.% compared with the NiBEA catalysts containing 4.1 and 6.0 wt.% nickel. Therefore, (1) the increase in the intensity of the peaks assigned to NiO with increasing nickel loading and consequently (2) reduction of the catalyst surface area measured by N2 adsorption experiments supports the hypothesis that large NiO clusters are formed on the NiBEA catalysts with increasing nickel loading and they block the pores of the catalyst, causing a reduction in surface area. A similar result was obtained by Martinez et al. using the same catalyst [6]. Fig. 1B shows the spectrum of the HBEA and NiBEA zeolite measured at 30 °C after the pre-treatment. The region between 4000 and 3000 cm−1 is assigned to the v(OH) of the BEA zeolites and the assignment of these peaks has been vastly reported in the literature [10–12,17,21–23]. Both spectra have an apparent peak at 3742 cm−1, which is assigned to the v(OH) of silanol groups. However, higher resolution results (4 cm−1, inset in Fig. 1B) actually show three peaks near this wavenumber. The peak at 3745 cm−1 is assigned to the v(OH) of the silanol groups at the external surface of the catalyst. On the other hand, the peaks at 3738 and 3728 cm−1 are assigned to silanol groups inside the pore structures. Furthermore, the peaks at 3670 and 3610 cm−1 are assigned to hydroxyl groups connected to aluminum in extra-framework positions and bridging hydroxyl groups, respectively. The bridging hydroxyl groups are characterized as strong Brønsted sites, which have been reported as the active site in oligomerization reactions over acidic heterogeneous catalysts [10–12]. Furthermore, additional peaks are present in the fingerprint region (ranging from 1500 to 600 cm−1). This region is important in the characterization of ion-exchanged zeolites, since it shows the stretching and bending modes of tetrahedral (T = Si or Al) atoms [17,24,25]. The peaks at 1230 and 1100 cm−1 are assigned to the intertetrahedral T–O asymmetrical vibrational mode of the BEA support. On the other hand, the peak at 800 cm−1 with a shoulder at 735 cm−1 is assigned to intertetrahedral symmetric T–O stretching mode. The peak with low intensity at 883 cm−1 is assigned to the vibrational mode of either Si–O or Al–O bonds [17,23]. This band arises from tri-coordinated aluminum atoms partly bonded to the BEA framework, where a hydroxyl group is attached and is characterized as a Lewis basic site [23]. The HBEA and NiBEA share most of the features assigned in the spectra presented in Fig. 1B. However, the peaks assigned to the v(OH) are less intense for the NiBEA than for the HBEA, with complete disappearance of the peaks at 3670 and 3610 cm−1, indicating substantial nickel exchange in the Brønsted sites. The hydroxyl groups connected to the framework aluminum have a strong acidic character; therefore, it is expected that nickel will exchange these sites more easily than the silanol groups, which have less acidic character. This result is supported by the absence of reflections for NiO species on the NiBEA catalyst with 1.0 wt.% nickel loading (Fig. 2), which, as already mentioned, does not guarantee the absence of NiO clusters, but suggests that most of the nickel species are present on the catalyst in exchanging form, rather than NiO clusters. Despite the weak acidic character of the silanol groups, the intensity of the peak at 3742 cm−1 also decreased after nickel exchange, with an additional decrease of the ratio of silanol groups outside/inside of the BEA structure. This is consistent with the formation of NiO clusters at the outer surface of the NiBEA catalyst as already demonstrated by the BET and XRD results. Therefore, not only the strong acid sites were substituted by nickel ions, but the formation of NiO clusters perturbed the weak acid sites. Because the Brønsted sites have a greater acidity than the silanol groups, we suggest that nickel exchanges the Brønsted sites and the reduction in the intensity of the peaks assigned to the silanol groups is exclusively caused by the formation of NiO clusters at the outer surface of the catalyst. Furthermore, the peak at 883 cm−1 also decreased after nickel exchange. The disappearance of this band after exchange with nickel indicates either leaching of Lewis basic sites due to the impregnation procedure (mixing in solution followed by thermal treatment) or modification in the chemical identity of these basic Lewis sites due to exchange of nearby Brønsted sites. The same trend was reported previously for the ion exchange of cesium in the hydrogen form of a commercial BEA zeolite [17]. The reduction in the intensity indicates that nickel ions exchanged sites in environments containing aluminum. 3.2 Effect of reaction conditions and parameters 3.2.1 Nature of adsorbed oligomers Fig. 3 shows the IR spectra of the HBEA and NiBEA (4.1 wt.% nickel loading) catalysts collected over the course of the ethylene oligomerization, at atmospheric pressure, varying the temperature from 30 to 300 °C. Peaks at 2956 and 2926 cm−1 are assigned to the v asym (CH3) and v asym (CH2), respectively. Also, a peak at 2863 cm−1 is observed. This peak arises from the overlapping of two other peaks at 2853 and 2869 cm−1, which are assigned to the v sym (CH3) and v sym (CH2), respectively [10–13,22]. Furthermore, the spectra of the outgassed NiBEA shows the absence of peaks above 3000 cm−1 indicating that the oligomers formed at the surface of the catalyst are not aromatic. This indication is consistent with the literature for the oligomerization of 1-hexene over HZSM-5 [13]. Additionally, recent publications from Martinez et al. and Olsbye et al. [26,27] showed that adsorbed species formed during the ethylene oligomerization over Ni-H-Beta are aliphatic. However, the series of spectra presented in Fig. 3 show that the HBEA catalyst is also active for the ethylene oligomerization. It is believed that ethylene oligomerization over purely acidic zeolites forms unstable carbocation intermediates at mild temperatures as opposed to higher olefins, such as propene and butene. However, in the 90's a study using in situ spectroscopy under ambient temperature showed that the oligomerization of ethylene over HZSM-5 proceeds via formation of a hydrogen-bonded π-complex followed by a protonation step and a similar spectra as the one shown in Fig. 3, for the HBEA catalyst, was reported. To validate this result, we performed the ethylene oligomerization over the HBEA catalyst using a packed bed reactor. We loaded pure HBEA catalyst in a packed bed reactor and used an on-line GC coupled with FID and TCD detectors to analyze the composition of the effluent of the reactor. The results are included in Fig. S3 and Table S3 (Supplementary Information). The results show the presence of a small fraction of desorbed products. Furthermore, the analysis of the spent catalyst indicates a high deposition of coke molecules on the catalyst surface. There is also a change in product distribution with increasing temperature from 150 to 300 °C. The increased formation of propylene under 300 °C as compared with 150 °C indicates a change in the reaction mechanism, which in this case favors the cracking of coke molecules into propylene. These results support our hypothesis that Brønsted acidic sites are able to oligomerize ethylene even at mild conditions without the assistance of metal catalysts. Since both catalysts are able to oligomerize ethylene, we assessed the effect of nickel on the catalytic reaction by the qualitative analysis of the collected liquid products. Since both catalysts are able to oligomerize ethylene, we assessed the effect of nickel on the catalytic reaction by the qualitative analysis of the collected liquid products. 3.2.2 Effect of nickel exchange and NiO In Fig. 3, the two catalysts show opposite behavior with respect to the production of oligomers at the catalyst surface with increasing temperature. It can be observed in Fig. 4 that both catalysts show an increase in the CH2/CH3 ratio with increasing temperature below 150 °C. However, when the temperature is increased over 150 °C, the CH2/CH3 decreases for the HBEA. On the other hand, for the NiBEA, the CH2/CH3 ratio keeps increasing, indicating that the chain growth continues beyond 150 °C. Furthermore, Fig. 4 shows that the total integrated intensity area of oligomers formed over the HBEA decreases when the temperature increases from 150 to 300 °C. In fact, there is a maximum at 150 °C for the HBEA catalyst. Conversely, for the NiBEA catalyst, the integrated intensity area keeps increasing with increasing temperature. This observation suggests that the HBEA catalyst, which has only acidic sites, starts to perform cracking of the oligomers which are adsorbed in the catalyst. Therefore, this indicates that above 150 °C, cracking reactions promoted by the acidic groups become prevalent over chain growth reactions. On the other hand, the NiBEA catalyst is able to maintain the chain growth, reducing the cracking of the oligomers. It is important to point out that there can still be some cracking of oligomers for the NiBEA catalyst, but the chain growth prevails in the entire range studied. Furthermore, for temperatures greater than 150 °C, the amount of oligomers on the NiBEA continues to increase despite the decrease of oligomers in the HBEA. This strongly suggests that coke is formed on nickel sites, in addition to being formed on acid sites. The nature of the active sites and the reaction mechanism involved in the initiation step was recently published in 2018 by Moussa et al., in which they show indications that ethylene undergoes oligomerization over Ni2+ species exchanging Brønsted sites over the NiBEA catalyst following a Cossee-Arlman mechanism [26]. In a recent publication from our research group, we found that NiBEA catalysts with nickel loading greater than 2.0 wt.% produced less coke relative to catalysts with nickel loadings lower than 2.0 wt.% and postulated that either Ni2+ or Ni+ species are the active sites in the ethylene oligomerization over nickel-exchanged aluminum silicate catalyst. Additionally, we found indications that the catalyst with nickel loading of 4.1 wt.% produces a greater amount of desorbed products as compared with catalysts containing less nickel (Fig. S4 – Supplementary Information). The higher activity of the NiBEA catalyst with nickel loading of 4.1 wt.% indicates participation of nickel species other than Ni2+ or Ni+, which are responsible for increasing product yields. It is believed that NiO species are inactive or spectators in the ethylene oligomerization over nickel aluminum silicate catalysts. However, this increase in product yields and decrease in coke at nickel loadings greater than 2.0 wt.% suggests the possibility that the NiO maintains the catalyst surface clean, acting perhaps as a promotor. Furthermore, Fig. 4 shows that the total integrated intensity area of oligomers formed over the HBEA decreases when the temperature increases from 150 to 300 °C. It is believed that NiO species are inactive or spectators in the ethylene oligomerization over nickel aluminum silicate catalysts. However, this increase in product yields and decrease in coke at nickel loadings greater than 2.0 wt.% suggests the possibility that the NiO maintains the catalyst surface clean, acting perhaps as a promotor. To validate this hypothesis, we produced a series of catalysts largely comprised of nickel exchanged sites. To achieve a high concentration of nickel exchanging sites, we performed consecutive nickel exchanging protocols using very low concentration of Ni(NO3)2 solutions. Fig S5 (Supplementary Information) shows that beyond a nickel loading of 1.37 wt.%, the mass of nickel exchanged between the solution and the catalyst becomes constant. This indicates saturation of exchanging sites, leading to the formation of NiO species. This is supported by the decrease in total surface area (Table S4 – Supplementary Information) specially affecting microporous structures, which indicates that in these cases, NiO species are small enough to block the microporous of the NiBEA catalysts. Comparison of the product selectivity and ethylene conversion for the ethylene oligomerization over the NiBEA 4.1 (Table S1 – Supplementary Information) and the NiBEA catalyst produced after 2 and 6 exchanges (Table S5 – Supplementary Information) shows an increased amount of heavy molecular weight compounds at 4.1 wt.% nickel loading. Indeed, most of the products formed with the catalysts produced after 2 and 6 exchanges (Table S5 – Supplementary Information) consist in C4 olefins. Furthermore, the catalysts produced from consecutive exchanges show a greater selectivity to coke as compared with the catalyst containing NiO in addition to nickel exchange sites. Therefore, based on these results, we believe it is possible that NiO plays an important role in the production of heavy molecular weight products by acting as a promotor removing coke from the catalyst surface. The GC–MS spectra of the liquid product collected in the impinger (Fig. S6 – Supplementary Information) for the oligomerization over the NiBEA catalyst shows mostly 1-butene followed by cis- and trans-butene, in addition to 1-hexene and 2-pentene-3-methyl. On the other hand, the reaction performed over the HBEA catalyst does not present any liquid products. The absence of products suggests that the cracking reactions lead to the formation of propane or propene, which was only partially collected in the impinger due to the very low boiling point. Moreover, after the conclusion of the reaction, some oligomers remained on the catalyst, as indicated in Fig. 3. Summarizing, these results indicate that (1) both NiBEA and HBEA catalysts are able to promote the oligomerization of ethylene, (2) coke and liquid products formed during the oligomerization of ethylene over the NiBEA catalyst are aliphatic, therefore, characterizing the coke as products which did not desorb from the catalyst surface, and (3) the NiBEA catalyst favors the desorption of products from the surface of the catalyst, compared to the HBEA catalyst, and reduces cracking reactions. The results presented support the reaction pathway for the ethylene oligomerization at atmospheric pressure shown in Fig. 5 . It is important to highlight that we focused on the development of reaction pathways for the ethylene oligomerization over the NiBEA catalyst. It is important to highlight that we focused on the development of reaction pathways for the ethylene oligomerization over the NiBEA catalyst. 3.2.3 Effect of the pressure and temperature on the overall ethylene oligomerization over the NiBEA (4.1 wt.%) catalyst Fig. 6 shows the ratio of CH2/CH3, calculated using IR spectra, for the oligomers adsorbed in the catalyst after the oligomerization of ethylene for a total reaction time of 100 minutes, as function of pressure and temperature. The number of carbons of the oligomers adsorbed increases with increasing ethylene partial pressure for all the conditions analyzed, except for the experiment carried out at 200 °C and 34.5 bar. Also, Fig. 7 A shows the selectivity for the product collected in the impinger for each reaction condition. As the pressure increases, the selectivity shifts to the formation of high molecular weight compounds. In fact, the increase of chain growth rates with increasing ethylene partial pressure has been reported in the literature for different silica–alumina catalyst, using both slurry and fixed-bed reactors [7–9,28,29]. Furthermore, Fig. 6 shows that the ratio of CH2/CH3 is greater for all the experiments conducted at 100 °C, compared to 30 and 200 °C. On the other hand, the analysis of the liquid collected in the impinger shows that the molecular weight of the liquid products increases with increasing temperature. Therefore, a significant portion of the heavy products formed during the reaction at 100 °C remained adsorbed on the catalyst. Conversely, for the experiments conducted at 200 °C, even though the FTIR data shows lower molecular weight compounds adsorbed on the catalyst, the analysis of the liquid collected in the impinger shows a greater selectivity for high molecular weight compounds. This is an indication that the desorption of the oligomers is affected by the temperature. Both the chain growth and desorption rates increase with increasing temperature. In other words, the CH2/CH3 ratios shown in Fig. 6 are affected by the relative contribution of the desorption and reaction steps. It is possible that a change in temperature from 100 °C to 200 °C increases the desorption rates to a higher extent than it increases the chain growth rates, leading to a reduction in CH2/CH3 ratio. 3.2.4 Effect of the pressure and temperature on coke formation Fig. 7B shows the spectra of the catalyst outgassed after the reaction, showing the CH stretching region. As already mentioned, the nature of the coke remaining on the catalyst after the reaction is aliphatic. For the experiment carried out at 30 °C and 6.9 bar, little coke is formed on the catalyst. This can be explained by low kinetic rates at this condition. In contrast, for the reactions performed at 100 and 200 °C (at 6.9 bar) the peaks associated with the oligomers adsorbed on the catalyst are much more intense, indicating that there are more oligomers adsorbed. Moreover, the experiments at 100 and 200 °C reveal that the reaction conducted at 34.5 bar formed less coke compared to the other two pressures. This result suggests that even though the reaction rate increased due to the increase of the ethylene partial pressure, the oligomers formed in the catalyst desorbed and diffused to the gas phase. 3.2.5 Effect of the pressure and temperature on liquid products composition For the series of experiments at 30 °C, only 1-butene was formed at 6.9 bar in the liquid product. This indicates that 1-butene is the first compound formed during the oligomerization of ethylene over the NiBEA catalyst. In fact, we showed previously that the experiments conducted at ambient pressure led to the formation of mostly 1-butene. As the temperature increases, cis/trans-butene are formed besides 1-butene. Indeed, 1-butene has already been postulated as the starting product of the ethylene oligomerization, and the isomerization of 1-butene to form cis/trans-butene has been shown to occur at elevated temperatures [3]. In addition, at 34.5 bar, it is possible to observe the formation of dimers, trimers and tetramers comprising both alpha olefins and its respective isomers. Additionally, compounds formed via cracking reactions are present in the liquid product. The GC–MS analysis of the liquid product collected for all the experiments performed above 6.9 bar shows 3-ethyl-1-pentene, 2,3-dimethyl-1-pentene, and 3-ethyl-3-heptene. This suggests that cracking reactions follow similar pathways above 6.9 bar, leading to the formation of similar oligomers for all experiments at these conditions. Nevertheless, it is important to highlight that, even though the cracking products are similar among themselves above 6.9 bar, the selectivity of the products formed from cracking reactions changes with temperature and pressure, as shown in Fig. 7A. One interesting observation is the presence of alpha-olefins (1-olefin) only up to C8. This might be an indication that (1) the products with more than 8 carbons are formed from the cracking of heavy molecular weight coke molecules, (2) they are formed from secondary chain growth reactions between oligomers produced from the primary oligomerization of ethylene, or (3) C10 and C10+ products are formed from the reaction of ethylene with C8 products formed from the isomerization of C8 alpha-olefins. Based on the products observed, we hypothesize that route (3) is the predominant one. 3.2.6 Effect of the subcritical and supercritical ethylene media Supercritical ethylene has a major effect in the oligomerization kinetics, as it can be observed in Fig. 6 that the CH2/CH3 ratio of the species in the catalyst is greater for all experiments conducted at the supercritical conditions (62 bar) compared to subcritical conditions (6.9 and 34.5 bar) at the same temperature. Also, Fig. 7B shows that the supercritical experiments formed more coke on the catalyst compared to the experiments in subcritical ethylene. It is important to point out that the increase of pressure from subcritical to supercritical increases the chain growth rates, therefore, increasing the coke formation rate at the catalyst surface. Therefore, the increase of the desorption constant in the supercritical region is not enough to suppress coke formation because of the increase of the chain growth rate. The analysis of the GC–MS data for the liquid product collected at supercritical ethylene phase shows heavy molecular weight oligomers in a greater concentration than what is observed in the subcritical experiments. This can be an indication of dissolution of the coke from the catalyst surface by the supercritical ethylene. The nature of the desorbed oligomers under supercritical conditions is similar to the desorbed products obtained in the experiments below the critical point. In fact, the molecules are olefins with a low degree of branching, and most of the compounds present one methyl or ethyl groups. However, the number of carbons increase beyond the critical point, with some molecules having up to 20 carbons. The presence of longer molecules at supercritical conditions is an indication that the desorption of heavier hydrocarbons is favored at these conditions. It is important to point out that, in previous work performed by our research group [20] with the NiBEA catalyst (different batch), the selectivity to C6 and C7 increase, and C8 and C9 decrease with the change from subcritical to supercritical conditions. We attributed this behavior to the increased solubility of butene and hexene under supercritical fluid conditions. However, no significant increase in the selectivity of C10+ products was observed. In the previous paper, we used an online analysis system with a column (Agilent HP-PLOT/Q, length = 30 m and inner diameter = 0.32 mm) which allowed analysis of products up to C12 and a maximum profile temperature of 260 °C. In the present paper, we used a different column, for general analysis (see Section 2.3 for additional information), and a maximum profile temperature of 300 °C. As mentioned in the experimental section, we identified products with up to 20 carbons using the MS. Therefore, this indicates that in the present paper we are covering a greater spectrum of products in the C10+ range relative to our previous work. The data presented in the previous set of experiments shows that both pressure and temperature increase the rate of the chain growth. Also, it is possible that the supercritical fluid acts as a solvent for the coke formed over the course of the reaction. The supercritical region is, among the conditions studied in this work, the preferable one for the oligomerization of ethylene over the NiBEA catalyst, since it presents a distribution of products shifted to heavier molecular weight compounds; therefore, indicating that (1) the catalyst is very active for chain growth at these conditions and (2) the desorption of coke is enhanced at supercritical conditions. Additionally, it is important to highlight that the higher ethylene conversions and catalyst stability obtained in our previous publication [20] under supercritical conditions relative to subcritical conditions shows that the increased formation of coke on the catalyst does not affect catalyst performance. The FTIR combined with the MS and FID provide some evidence of the dissolution of coke at supercritical conditions. However, we were able to obtain even stronger evidence in the set of experiments that follows. Fig. 8 shows the proposed reaction pathway for the ethylene oligomerization at a temperature range of 30–200 °C, and a pressure range of 6.9–62 bar, based on a qualitative analysis of the liquid products collected and identified after the reaction. 3.3 Analysis of the effects of supercritical fluid conditions Table 2 compares the product selectivity of the liquids collected for one subcritical and the two supercritical conditions from Table 1. The selectivity for C3–C5 decreases as the reaction conditions change from subcritical to supercritical, and it further decreases with the change from supercritical to dense supercritical. On the other hand, the selectivity for heavy molecular weight hydrocarbons (products ranging from C9 to C10+) increases, with a greater selectivity for heavier molecular weight compounds at the dense supercritical condition. The shift of the product selectivity to heavier molecular weight compounds when the conditions change from subcritical to supercritical was already discussed in the previous section. However, in the set of experiments discussed here, the system operates at an ethylene flow rate of 165 ml/min, as opposed to 15 ml/min for the experiments described in Section 3.2. Therefore, it is expected for the mass transfer convection rate of the products in the supercritical ethylene to increase, thus, removing more heavy compounds adsorbed on the catalyst. Also, the decrease in the selectivity of C3 and C5 indicates that the cracking of C6 and C10 is minimized at supercritical conditions. Instead, the cracking reactions affect large molecular weight compounds to a greater extent, with an increase in the selectivity of C9. The formation of heavier compounds followed by the desorption from the catalyst surface at supercritical conditions is evident in Table 2. In summary, the experiment at dense supercritical fluid conditions provides strong evidence of (1) enhancement of the kinetics of chain growth under SCFC, and (2) dissolution of the coke formed in the NiBEA catalyst by the supercritical ethylene. Fig. 9 presents a set of pictures of the pressurization and reaction processes. The picture of the fresh catalyst is displayed for comparison. Initially, it is possible to observe a change in the catalyst surface color from white (Fig. 9A – before pre-treatment) to beige, as a result of the thermal treatment (Fig. 9A – after pre-treatment). Also, when the system is pressurized to the set point, no change in the catalyst surface color can be observed (Fig. 9A – 57 bar, 200 °C). As mentioned in Section 2.3.2, a flow rate of 600 ml/min of pure ethylene was used to pressurize the reactor. Therefore, if any chemical reaction occurred during this process, its extent was not high enough to change the catalyst color. However, once the pressure and temperature reached the set point (Fig. 9A – 57 bar, 200 °C), the flow rate of ethylene was reduced to 165 ml/min to initiate the reaction. Fig. 9B shows the pictures of the catalyst surface in different time intervals over the course of the reaction. When the flow rate is reduced, the catalyst becomes more active for the oligomerization and its surface starts to become dark. After 20 min, the catalyst surface is completely dark. The dark aspect of the catalyst is an indication of coke formation. The visual observation of this material deposited on the surface of the catalyst suggests that it is a macrostructure resembling a polymer. Additionally, it is interesting that this material forms on top of the catalyst bed, therefore, on the outer surface of the catalyst, indicating that this coke is not formed due to internal diffusion limitation of large hydrocarbons (although coke can still form inside the pores of the NiBEA catalyst). As discussed previously in Section 3.2, the coke studied in this work is constituted of aliphatic molecules [16] which suggests that the material shown in Fig. 9.B is composed by C–C (sp3) bonds. Furthermore, in Section 3.2.3, we calculated a CH2/CH3 ratio between 6 and 7 for the species adsorbed on the catalyst under the same conditions, which indicates that this macromolecule have a low degree of branching. After 60 minutes of TOS, the catalyst surface color starts to become clear (Frame B – 60 min) and after the total reaction time (Frame B – 100 min) the catalyst surface resembles the catalyst before the reaction (Fig. 9A – 57 bar, 200 °C). This variation in color shows that, in fact, the supercritical ethylene dissolved the coke formed at the surface of the catalyst bed. We also tested the effect of the supercritical ethylene on the dissolution of coke from the HBEA catalyst. Fig. S7 (Supplementary Information) shows the pictures of the catalysts collected after reaction under near supercritical and dense supercritical conditions. It is possible to observe that the experiment under subcritical conditions produced a dark material on the catalyst, which corroborates the formation of coke at the outer surface of the catalyst as already mentioned. Conversely, the spent catalyst collected after the ethylene oligomerization under supercritical conditions does not contain this dark material. Therefore, this observation supports our initial hypothesis that supercritical ethylene solubilize coke molecules from the catalyst surface. To the best of our knowledge, this work is the first to provide visual evidence of the dissolution of the coke formed during chemical reactions over heterogeneous catalysts under supercritical conditions, and although the enhanced solvating effect of the supercritical ethylene has already been reported in the literature, to the best of our knowledge this is the first work to show the phenomenon in situ during the reaction. Nevertheless, one question remains: What causes the products to stay adsorbed on the catalyst? We previously showed that both the coke and the desorbed products are aliphatic, and no information about the degree of branching or nature of the coke was attained in the previous sections. The second experiment (described in Section 2.3.2) was used to answer this question. Instead of using a TOS of 100 min, we performed the experiment for a shorter time to collect the coke material from the reactor and perform the characterization. Since the experiment at dense supercritical condition produced more coke compared to the other two experiments, we repeated this experiment, however, using a TOS equal to 50 min. We observed that the dark material which was adsorbed at 57 bar desorbed at the end of the experiment, after depressurization. In addition, a layer of liquid (some visible droplets) formed on the inner surface of the window (see supplementary information – Fig. S8). We collected the liquid formed on the inner surface of the window and analyzed it using the GC–MS. Fig. 10 presents some of the compounds identified, which shows that this liquid is formed mostly by highly branched cyclic aliphatic hydrocarbons. It is important to note that we believe that the cyclic molecules shown in Fig. 10 originate from larger structures on the catalytic structure composed of interconnected cyclic species, and the decomposition of these large molecular structures during depressurization generates the cyclic species that we identified. Therefore, this strongly indicates that the macromolecule, which clearly formed on the catalyst surface (Fig. 9B) under supercritical conditions, is formed by cyclic molecules connected via C–C (sp3) bonds. However, once the pressure drops below the ethylene critical pressure (51.2 bar), this material decomposes, generating the molecules shown in Fig. 10. For the experiment performed at supercritical ethylene for 100 min, the GC–MS analysis of the liquid collected in the impinger shows peaks assigned to cyclic molecules with a high degree of branching, supporting the characterization of the liquid collect on the inner window of the reactor. Conversely, the formation of coke on the catalyst surface was not observed for the experiment conducted at 57 bar and 100 °C, and the experiment conducted at subcritical conditions did not present any of these compounds in the liquid products. We observed that the dark material which was adsorbed at 57 bar desorbed at the end of the experiment, after depressurization. In addition, a layer of liquid (some visible droplets) formed on the inner surface of the window (see supplementary information – Fig. S8). We collected the liquid formed on the inner surface of the window and analyzed it using the GC–MS. Fig. 10 presents some of the compounds identified, which shows that this liquid is formed mostly by highly branched cyclic aliphatic hydrocarbons. It is important to note that we believe that the cyclic molecules shown in Fig. 10 originate from larger structures on the catalytic structure composed of interconnected cyclic species, and the decomposition of these large molecular structures during depressurization generates the cyclic species that we identified. Therefore, this strongly indicates that the macromolecule, which clearly formed on the catalyst surface (Fig. 9B) under supercritical conditions, is formed by cyclic molecules connected via C–C (sp3) bonds. However, once the pressure drops below the ethylene critical pressure (51.2 bar), this material decomposes, generating the molecules shown in Fig. 10. For the experiment performed at supercritical ethylene for 100 min, the GC–MS analysis of the liquid collected in the impinger shows peaks assigned to cyclic molecules with a high degree of branching, supporting the characterization of the liquid collect on the inner window of the reactor. Conversely, the formation of coke on the catalyst surface was not observed for the experiment conducted at 57 bar and 100 °C, and the experiment conducted at subcritical conditions did not present any of these compounds in the liquid products. Finally, we hypothesize that the high ethylene partial pressure (above critical point) enhances the oligomerization rates forming visible coke on the catalyst at the beginning of the reaction. However, over an extended period of time, the supercritical ethylene is also responsible for the dissolution of this material from the catalyst surface. It is important to highlight that the supercritical ethylene solubilized coke molecules from both HBEA and NiBEA catalysts, therefore, showing the standalone effect of the supercritical ethylene toward the dissolution of coke from the catalyst surface without even requiring the presence of the active metal center for this phenomenon to occur. Furthermore, the increased formation of coke at the beginning of the reaction under supercritical conditions does not impact the catalyst lifetime since the supercritical ethylene dissolves this material over the reaction period. Additionally, previous publications [15] from our research group show higher ethylene conversion under supercritical conditions as opposed to subcritical conditions with a lower catalyst deactivation, which supports this observation. These results combined support the conclusion that (1) the reaction kinetics is enhanced, and (2) the coke is dissolved at supercritical conditions. In summary, we characterized the coke at supercritical conditions as macromolecules connected by C–C (sp3) bonds with the occurrence of cyclic species composing this network. 4 Conclusion We reported in this paper a study of the catalytic reactions of ethylene oligomerization over a nickel supported in aluminum silicate catalyst with a BEA topology under subcritical and supercritical conditions. The N2 adsorption shows a reduction of the catalyst BET surface area with increasing Ni(NO3)2 concentration, which indicates the deposition of NiO in the catalyst surface. The oligomerization experiments show that the protonated form of the commercial support is able to oligomerize ethylene, however, producing mostly adsorbed products. Additionally, the catalyst containing only acidic sites forms strongly adsorbed species leading to coke formation and promotes the cracking of the products (likely producing propene) for temperatures higher than 150 °C. On the other hand, the catalyst exchanged with nickel maintains the chain growth, leading to the formation of desorbed products. In addition, the nature of the coke is aliphatic. Screening experiments show that the increase of pressure and temperature increase both the chain growth rates and the desorption of oligomers from the catalyst surface. However, the increase in the reaction kinetics at supercritical conditions is greater than the increase of the desorption rate, leading to the deposition of additional coke at the catalyst surface. However, the supercritical ethylene promotes the dissolution of the coke hydrocarbons from the catalyst surface. We were able to obtain visual confirmation of the phenomena in situ and identification of the coke at supercritical conditions macromolecules connected via C–C (sp3) bonds with occurrence of cyclic species, which we validated using GC–MS/FID. Finally, we postulated reaction pathways based on the results obtained. coredata.dc:description: We report a study of the catalytic reactions of ethylene oligomerization over nickel impregnated in aluminum silicate using subcritical and supercritical media. We found the BET surface area decreases with increasing nickel loading, indicating the deposition of NiO particles on the catalyst surface, which we confirmed via XRD. We compared the performance of the NiBEA catalyst with the protonated form (HBEA) of the commercial support and obtained strong evidence that the protonated form promotes chain growth reactions. In addition, the introduction of nickel in the catalyst facilitates the desorption of the oligomers compared to the HBEA catalyst. Additionally, we used FTIR and GC–MS/FID to characterize the adsorbed and desorbed oligomers and developed reaction pathways for the ethylene oligomerization over the NiBEA catalyst. We found that both adsorbed and desorbed oligomers are aliphatic, and the non-desorbed products constitute the coke. Additionally, we found that pressure and temperature both increase the chain growth and desorption rates of adsorbed oligomers. Under supercritical conditions, the amount of coke formed on the catalyst and the desorbed products molecular weight both increase relative to subcritical conditions. However, the supercritical conditions promote the dissolution of the coke from both NiBEA and HBEA catalysts, which shows the standalone effect of the supercritical ethylene toward the dissolution of coke from the catalyst surface. We provided visual evidence of (1) the formation of coke on the catalyst surface, and (2) the coke dissolution phenomena under supercritical conditions. Finally, we characterized the coke molecules at supercritical conditions as macromolecules connected via C-C (sp3) bonds with the occurrence of cyclic species.
coredata.dc:title: Study of the catalytic reactions of ethylene oligomerization in subcritical and supercritical media over a NiBEA catalyst
